abstract.para: This chapter explains how to restrict access to the &crond; and at daemons to improve the security of a system.

sect1.title: Restricting the &crond; daemon
sect1.para: The &crond; system is used to automatically run commands in the background at predefined times. For more information about &crond;, refer to the .

The cron.allow file specifies a list of users that are allowed to execute jobs via &crond;. The file does not exist by default, so all users can create &crond; jobs—except for those listed in cron.deny.

procedure.para: To prevent users except for &rootuser; from creating &crond; jobs, perform the following steps.

step.para: Allow users to create &crond; jobs by adding their usernames to the file:
To verify, try creating a &crond; job as non-root user listed in cron.allow. You should see the message:
step.screen: &prompt.user1;crontab -e no crontab for &exampleuser_plain; - using an empty one
step.para: Quit the crontab editor and try the same with a user not listed in the file (or before adding them in step 2 of this procedure):
step.screen: &prompt.user2;crontab -e You (&exampleuserII_plain;) are not allowed to use this program (crontab) See crontab(1) for more information

important.title: Existing &crond; jobs
important.para: Implementing cron.allow only prevents users from creating new &crond; jobs. Existing jobs will still be run, even for users listed in cron.deny. To prevent this, create the file as described and remove existing user crontabs from the directory /var/spool/cron/tabs to ensure they are not run anymore.

note.title: Switching to &systemd; timer units
note.para: You should also consider switching to &systemd; timer units, as they allow for more powerful and reliable task execution. By default, users cannot use them to run code when they are not logged in. This limits the way users can interact with the system while not being connected to it.
For more information about &systemd; timer units, refer to .

sect1.title: Restricting the at scheduler
sect1.para: The at job execution system allows users to scheduled one-time running jobs. The at.allow file specifies a list of users that are allowed to schedule jobs via at. The file does not exist by default, so all users can schedule at jobs—except for those listed in at.deny)

note.title: Uninstalling at
note.para: at is not widely used anymore. If you do not have valid use cases, consider uninstalling the daemon instead of just restricting its access.
